holdings.reasoning_summary: Assignment deed expressly states assignees take as joint tenants; deed approved by lessors; standard rule that notice to one joint tenant binds all.

holdings.text: The Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging Houses Rates Control Act, 1947 does not apply to a suit for eviction from land belonging to a local authority by virtue of s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: It must not be overlooked that the suit was for eviction from the land only Under the Rent Control Act, the word premises is defined by s.5 (8) inter alia, as follows Premises means-    any land-not being used for agricultural purposes. The Act, prior to its amendment in 1953 by the Bombay Act IV

holdings.reasoning_summary: Premises includes land per s.5(8); s.4(1) provides absolute exemption for premises belonging to local authority; first part of s.4(1) general and unqualified.

holdings.text: Section 4(4)(a) of the Bombay Rents Act excludes from the exemption in s.4(1) only buildings erected on land held from a local authority, and does not extend to the land itself.

anchor.surface_text: . 4 (a) . The expression premises belonging to the Government or a local au- thority in sub-section (1) shall, notwithstanding anything contained in the said sub- section or in any judgment. decree or order of a Court, not include a building erected on any land held by any person from the Government or a local authority under an agreement, lease or other grant, although having regard to the provisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history post-Bhatia: amendment targets buildings to protect sub-tenants; uses 'building' not 'premises'; phrase 'erected on land held...' describes qualifying buildings.

holdings.text: The Bombay City Civil Court had jurisdiction to entertain the suit for eviction from land belonging to the Port Trustees; the suit need not be filed in the Court of Small Causes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rent Control Act inapplicable to land eviction per s.4(1); jurisdiction follows from Act's non-applicability.

holdings.text: The contract requiring delivery of vacant possession of the land is enforceable and not impossible of performance notwithstanding any protection the appellant's sub-tenants may have.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 1942 lease granted land together with existing buildings; monthly tenancy precarious and terminable by notice under Transfer of Property Act; no need to opine on sub-tenants eviction.

holdings.text: Sub-section (1) of s.4 of the Bombay Rents Act has three distinct parts, with the first providing a general absolute exemption for premises belonging to Government or local authority.

anchor.surface_text: This Court pointed out that sub-s. (1) of s. 4 had three parts viz. (1) this Act shall not apply to premises belonging to the Government or a local authority (2) this Act shall not apply as against the Government to any tenancy or other like relationship created by a grant from the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. v. D. Patel; textual parsing confirms first part unqualified.

holdings.text: The suit as laid for vacant possession of the land in the City Civil Court was competent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of inapplicability of Rent Act to land eviction, proper jurisdiction, and enforceable tenancy terms.

precedents.citation: Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. v. D. Patel 1

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of this Court is reported in Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. v. D. Patel 1 . In that case, building sites were auctioned in 1908 by the City Improvement Trust, Bombay. One of the companyditions of the sale was that the bidder should companystruct a building, on the site, of a certain value and according to a plan approved by the City Improvement Trust. One Sitaram Laxman was the highest bidder, and he companystructed a building. as agreed.

precedents.case_name: Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. v. D. Patel
precedents.cited_proposition: Sub-section (1) of section 4 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 exempts premises belonging to Government or local authority from the Act's operation; exemption is general and absolute; land and buildings on such premises belong to the lessor/local authority
precedents.cited_holding: the lessor after the building was erected became the owner of it and all the time thereafter the demised premises which include the building have belonged to him subject to the right of enjoyment of the lessee in terms of the lease

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge following a decision of the Bombay High Court reported in Ram Bhagwandas v. Bombay Corporation 1 . In that case, one Khudabaksh Irani had I.R, 1956. Bow. 364. taken lease of certain plots some 30 years back., and companystructed some structures upon the open plot, and rented them out as tenements. In 1947, Irani sold them to one Tyaballi.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sub-section 4(a) of section 4 protects tenants in buildings erected on land held from local authority under agreement requiring construction, but protection is for buildings only, not land; phrase 'erected on any land held...' is descriptive and test applies at time protection is claimed

anchor.surface_text: Such a situation had also arisen in the case of the Bombay High Court in Ram Bhagwandas v. Bombay Corporation 1 , and the assignee of the lessee was unable to deliver vacant possession.
